http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The South-East Asia Communications system terminated in Cairns, Australia, where it was linked via a microwave link to Sydney. But as one engineer recalls, this last wireless segment “was nothing but trouble. The cable would often just continually fail. Not because of the cable system, but the backhaul link between Cairns and Sydney.”

On the northwestern edge of Australia, Cairns gazes out across a serene blue-green sea. These peaceful waters are deceptive – underneath the surface there are mud flats, and farther out to sea, the Great Barrier Reef. The muddy, shallow bottom of the ocean means that Cairns is not the beach town it would seem destined to be. It caters primarily to tourists who stop by on their way to the reef, the area’s main attraction, which draws in flows of visitors every year, many of whom rely on the area's communications networks. In 1967, Cairns received its first cable, a link to Papua New Guinea, extending onward to Guam and Hong Kong. Nine years later, a second link was set up between Cairns and Papua New Guinea. The city remained a sort of branch outpost for Australia, a landing point for cables on the country's northern coast, until APNG was withdrawn from service in 1996. While its location at the tip of Australia makes it a natural outlet to Asia, the inland cable that connected these networks to Sydney has often caused problems, and the Great Barrier Reef, challenging to cross using cables, makes it difficult to bring signals in and out from abroad.

Madang is fairly small as far as cities go – about 30,000 people live here – but it is the capital and most populous part of its province. The city’s infrastructure is focused outward rather than inward. It is home to many of Papua New Guinea’s export industries, and the landing point for an international fiber-optic cable. The main occupation for many here is a large timber industry, which logs the nearby Gogol forest. In addition, the city exports copra, coconuts, coffee, cocoa, and tobacco, and is home to tuna processing plants and engineering and joinery workshops. The people are also a mix – tourists, missionaries, and contract workers from countries around the world mingle with indigenous people speaking hundreds of different local languages. Papua New Guinea is considered one of the most culturally diverse places in the world, with over 800 different languages spoken by people living mainly in traditional tribal societies. Only a small percentage live in urban, modernized centers like Madang and Port Moresby. But even cities within the country have trouble interacting with each other: the volcanoes that run through the middle of the island have prevented any roads from being built between them.
<!--EndFragment-->

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Tourists step on a long cable conduit without looking twice, intent on getting to the ruins of an Japanese antiaircraft gun constructed during World War II at the far end of Gun Beach. Guam held strategic military value in part due to its position as a cable hub. At the other end of the beach is the Hotel Nikko, one of the early Japanese five star hotels in the area, a structure dependent on the island’s advanced communications  infrastructure. Undersea cables, shuttling signals to the United States, Australia, and Japan, bisect a material remnant of the Japanese wartime attack and one of the largest indications of Japanese development on the island, two sites with which undersea cables are intertwined. The cable conduits themselves are worn down and blend in with the rocks on the beach. In the water their surfaces are smooth, but rippled, like the ocean. In them, you can see traces of the atmospheric and geological currents that have long positioned the island as central to transpacific movement. Tumon Bay is a node in the cable network, a point of interconnection and redistribution, not simply of electronic signals, but of cultural and political currents.

The Deep Water Bay cable station is situated on one of the most expensive properties in our undersea network. Overlooking a small bay on Hong Kong’s south shore, the station was built when there was little development in the area. Today, it is the oldest still operational station on the island and has been the connection point for numerous cables since the 1960s. In the intervening years, Hong Kong’s affluent residents migrated to the nearby hills and the area’s forest was replaced with mansions. Unlike the typical windowless structures that populate the cable system, Deep Water Bay’s postwar architecture offers a lookout onto the beaches and ocean below. Peering out of the station windows, you have a better view of the bay than Hong Kong’s richest man. There are few people here to enjoy it, however: since it opened, machines have replaced many of the workers.

Kota Kinabalu is known as KK to many Malaysians and internationals, but locals also call it Api-Api, its original indigenous name, meaning fire. The rapidly growing capital of the eastern Malaysian state, Sabah, is today a culturally, ethnically, and religiously diverse city of half a million people. Many of the country’s banks and insurance companies have their headquarters in tall office buildings clustered at the edge of the sea. From 1964 to 1986, the SEACOM cable connected the city to Singapore, and onward to the global network. This was followed by a fiber-optic link, laid in 1992. KK’s status as an economic and industrial center was prefigured by the British development of its port during the colonial period. The harbor’s connection with the Asian mainland is far more ancient than either the cable or the colony, however. KK is named after nearby Mount Kinabalu, the tallest mountain in the Malay archipelago. Legend has it that Kinabalu is derived from the words for “Chinese Widow.” Long ago, the legend tells, a Chinese prince was shipwrecked in the area and fell in love with a local woman. He returned to China, but promised to come back for her. Every day at sunrise, she would make a pilgrimage to the top of the mountain to look for his ship, until one day she died on the cold summit. The spirit of the mountain turned her face into a rock facing the sea, so that she could always look out towards China.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Note: unconfirmed that SEACOM landed at Katong; not sure if image matches landing

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Long before it was a cable hub, Katong was a center of private wealth in British Malaya. Colonial elites established giant mansions, coconut plantations, and weekend villas along the waterfront in this East Singapore district beginning in the early nineteenth century. Though some of these structures have been preserved and restored, often painted bright colors, the still-affluent neighborhood has also seen some major physical transformations. The beach where you emerge from the APCN-2 network didn’t even exist before the 1970s. It was created as part of a massive land-reclamation project designed to add more space for housing on the island. Modern apartment towers and Singapore’s largest park now occupy the expanded coastal area. Soon after the artificial beach was completed, a telephone cable arrived from Hong Kong, followed by connections to regional fiber-optic networks in the 1990s and early 2000s.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: This tag specifies that the associated page is a cable.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Across history, there have been three kinds of cable technology: copper telegraph cables, coaxial telephone cables, and fiber-optic internet cables. To create a page for a new cable, see the reference page for cables.

During the coaxial years, the British Commonwealth staged a number of globe-spanning projects, including COMPAC, ANZCAN, and SEACOM, to bridge the gaps between Commonwealth countries. Following the routes of the colonial cable systems, these networks were intended to take up where colonization had left off.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Long before Bandon became AT&T’s outpost in rural Oregon, it was a critical node in an undersea cable network: the U.S. military’s Sound Surveillance System (SOSUS). From the Pacific coast, SOSUS connected hydrophones and picked up sonic traces of subaquatic movements, from the deployment of Soviet submarines to migrations of whales. Officers stationed at Naval Facility Coos Head tuned into these underwater listening posts and collected data on enemy operations. The Coos Head facility, first opened in 1958, was closed twenty-nine years later in 1987. Improvements in signal-processing had replaced manpower with computers, and as the Cold War wound down the number of Naval Facilities was reduced. Given AT&T’s tight ties with the U.S. Navy, and their assistance in developing SOSUS, it was unsurprising when nine years later, they chose Bandon as a landing point for their newest transpacific cable system, TPC-5.

Central California has been a cable hub since 1964, when a telephone cable to Hawai'i was routed through Morro Bay. The first station in the area was constructed by AT&T, and its location midway between San Francisco and Los Angeles placed it out of the way of potential nuclear attack. 

Although the state has been a hub in communication technology, it has also played an important role in the growth of the environmental movement, pioneered breakthroughs in environmental policy, and is committed to the preservation of wilderness areas. Daniel Press articulates the apparent contradiction: “at the vanguard of paradoxical trends, California is one of the fastest growing states in the country, but is the most ambivalent about change.” Today there are increasing conflicts between these two forces.

Completed in 2000, the consortium-owned China-U.S. Cable Network was the first direct cable route between the two countries. It consists of dual Pacific crossings, forming a ring structure with connections along the west coast of the U.S. and between several Southeast Asian hubs. Only a year after it entered service, however, the anchor of a fishing boat off Chongming Island disrupted much of the traffic between China and the U.S..

Built by the Eastern Extension, Australasia and China Telegraph Company between 1901 and 1902, this cable was part of a larger project to connect Australia and London via British colonies in the Indian Ocean and South Africa.

Typhoons and loneliness were the greatest perils for the cablemen working on the Cocos Islands in the early and middle twentieth century. Like Midway Island, the Cocos were largely uninhabited before the establishment of a cable station in 1901. The station was built at the highest point on the island: two meters above the high water mark, but this didn't keep it from damage during cyclones in 1907, 1911, and 1933. These caused flooding, collapsed palm trees onto the cable station houses, and wreaked havoc for international communications. During quieter moments, cablemen played tennis, worked, and waited eagerly for the arrival of supply ships every three months to bring food, mail, and mild excitement. Today, tourists seek out the Cocos for their quietude and isolation, sparsely and silently scattering themselves across the white beaches and blue-green waters. Floating just above the ocean’s surface, these low-lying islands still hold tropical forests, surrounded by soft beaches. There are no hills or mountains on the Cocos, and pools of fresh water collect here and there in the soil when it rains. True to their name, the islands’ sole export is coconuts, which hang heavily from palm trees everywhere you look.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: On the south-western coast of Australia, Cottesloe is a popular beach town and a comfortable suburb of Perth, the largest city in Western Australia. Green manicured lawns lead to soft white beaches, where families picnic and groups of people play beach cricket. When the beach is quieter, you might run across a troop of wild kangaroos rummaging through the garbage or sunning themselves on the sand. A few miles inland, the city of Perth rises above the beaches. Skyscrapers reflect the southern sun and sailboats dot the harbor. Over a century ago, in 1901, Cottesloe was chosen as the endpoint for the trans-Indian Ocean telegraph cable. The Eastern Extension Cable Company built its cable station, a bunker-like red brick building, at the edge of the ocean, on a rocky, limestone coast abutting the sea. At the southernmost end of “The Esplanade,” a wide grassy park that still exists today, the men in this building received signals from the cable and transmitted them via landline to Perth, already an established city by the time the cable station was built, with shops, streetcars, and a railway station. The cablemen had busy jobs in an exciting port, transmitting news to and from the city at all hours, every day. In this way, even though they were remotely located, they remained connected and integral to the fast-paced, urban life. In 1937, the Manager of the Cable Station boasted that “the only time throughout the entire year when there is a cessation of activity in these stations, is on Armistice Day, when the instruments are closed down for a period of two minutes.”

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Margaret Miller, Gentlemen of the Cable Service: A Pictorial History of Australia’s Overseas Cable Telecommunications Service, 1870-1934 (Sydney: OTC Australia and Publimedia, 1992), 10.
“A Fifteen Minute Broadcast Given by Mr. H. A. Colliver of Cottesloe Branch,” The Zodiac (1937): 276.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In the 19th century, the first undersea network extended around the globe. The British pioneered this effort, drawing upon their technical expertise and naval resources. Many of these early systems followed colonial transportation and trade routes.

This was the first submarine telegraph line to Australia, laid by the British Australian Telegraph Company in 1871. Here it connected to the Overland Telegraph, which stretched almost 2,000 miles south to Adelaide. Although the undersea cable reached Darwin before the terrestrial link, it was severed in the ocean only shortly thereafter. Finally, after the submarine cable was repaired, Australia was enfolded into the British colonial network.

Banyuwangi means "Fragrant Water" in Javanese. Landing on its shores in the late nineteenth century, you emerge from vibrant blue waves. A gateway between Asia and Australia, this Dutch colony is a key stopping point for telegraph cables. In 1871 a link to Darwin was landed here, connecting Australia to the rest of the world through Java’s shores. While more a century in the future, surfers will travel from around the world to ride Banyuwangi’s waves, nineteenth-century cablemen complain that its waters were “uninviting” because of the “ever-present danger of crocodiles and sharks.” Here the cable intersects both turbulent waters and an ancient spiritual history. From the sixteenth to eighteenth century, the city was the capital of the Hindi Kingdom of Blambangan, which controlled the eastern tip of Java before it was taken over by the Dutch. To dig a trench for the telegraph cable to Singapore, native convicts were employed as laborers. But when they unearthed a Hindu Temple from 700 AD, the laborers refused to continue and women, who reportedly were unaffected by the native “superstitions,” had to be called in to complete the job.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: “Imagine yourself in a black room, with most of the light and air cut off by screens, and blinds, a mirror lamp burning close to you, and a temperature of about 95 in the shade,” recounts one cable worker of his time in Darwin. Conditions were rough for the early operators at Australia’s first undersea telegraph station, which hooked the continent into the colonial network in 1871. In the summer the temperature was often over 100 degrees Fahrenheit, even despite the Hindu and Aboriginal servants employed to “waft away the heat.” The quarters of the telegraph men frequently flooded and stores often ran out of rations. When the cable was first landed, the men’s quarters had not even built, and for two years they lived in tents. During this time the terrestrial cable, linking Darwin to Adelaide, went out frequently, cut by Aborigines across the continent. Even despite the hardships, the cablemen were still a privileged lot in this colonial outpost. Their rooms, once built, were “lofty,” and their station was eventually furnished with amenities like a piano and billard table. “Perhaps the the greatest luxury they can boast of,” one reported, “is plenty of water gratis, for which others have to pay ninepence per bucket.”

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: 1883-?; Telcon; Great Northern Telegraph Company; Store Nordiske (See AtlanticCable.com)

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: At the request of the Japanese government, the Great Northern Telegraph Company laid the first cable under the Korean Strait in 1883. The cable linked Nagasaki via Japan’s Tsushima Island to Pusan (now officially spelled Busan), the first international port in Korea and a major Japanese settlement.

This Korean city has long been a hub for Japanese connections. In the nineteenth century it was the primary access point for Japanese merchants to Asian trade networks. When it opened, Pusan’s Japanese-run telegraph station became an equally important gateway. It handled all Korean telegraph traffic until an overland link to Seoul was completed in 1888, and it allowed Japanese-language telegrams to leave the country for the first time. Cable traffic spiked from a few thousand messages sent between the two countries in 1884 to some 430,000 — the vast majority were in Japanese. In 1931, Pusan was the site of Japanese experiments for another communications revolution: the use of undersea cables for voice transmission.

If you could climb up the deep green mountains on the northern end of this island, and look west across the water, you would see the hills of the Korean peninsula rising above Pusan. A small island, about 700 square kilometers of land, Tsushima is equidistant between the Japanese mainland and Korea. Because of its location, it had been a trade center for centuries before the cables arrived, and since has been a perfect locale for international cable connections as well as a strategic military node. Five different cables have landed here since 1891. In 1905, during the Russo-Japanese War, a decisive battle was fought in the waters around the island, which the Japanese won largely through their adeptness with wireless telegraphy. Yet this did not lead to the scrapping of “older” cable systems. Quite the opposite. After the war, the Japanese immediately laid a new undersea telegraph cable: wires complement, rather than replace, wireless.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Like many port cities in Asia, Nagasaki was “discovered” by imperial powers – in this case, the Portuguese – and developed for trade. In the nineteenth century, Nagasaki became a busy transit point, with a vibrant ship-building industry, an anchorage site for the Japanese navy, and a telegraph cable landing point. Three years after its first submarine telegraph cable was landed in 1871, the telegraph company established a headquarters here, in a large two-story office building abutting the harbor. Within a few years, Japan would build up its internal landlines, and the country would be connected to the rest of the world via Nagasaki. The importance of this station was clear to Japan and its enemies. Described as “clutching the aeortic artery of international communications in Japan,” Nagasaki, as a hub and military harbor, was also a target. The cable to Vladivostok was taken out of service during the Russo-Japanese War, but the city remained undamaged. During World War II, however, Nagasaki was hit with the atomic bomb, the second and last to ever be deployed, killing several hundred thousand people. After the Japanese surrender, the city would slowly rebuild. Old communications lines were taken out of service, and new coaxial cables laid in their place.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Since the 1880s, Chikura has been known for precision exercises tied to the ocean. Every year, a knife ceremony is held at a local shrine dedicated to the gods of seasoning and culinary arts. Seven or eight men fillet and plate a whole carp using nothing but a twenty-inch blade and a pair of foot-long chopsticks, honoring the town’s legacy as a fishing community. In 1989, Chikura became a site of underwater cable innovation. The first fiber-optic line between the U.S. and Japan landed here, less than fifty miles from central Tokyo, followed by many other cables in the 1990s and 2000s. More recently, the town has become a surfing hub. Several professional competitions are held on Setohama Beach, where well-formed waves crash opposite the prominent cable station.

Port Alberni draws its wealth from the vast forest of British Columbia’s shores. Deep inland, sheltered from the Pacific Ocean by a long, narrow inlet, the town’s early dwellers worked at waterfront mills, stripping the woods around them to make products that circled the globe. By the 1960s, many residents worked for MacMillan Bloedel, one of the world’s largest forestry companies. It not only boosted the region’s economy, but each of its divisions had its own social club, organizing social gatherings of all kinds and structuring local life. Yet in the 1960s and 70s, a new constituency began to oppose the logging of Vancouver Island. Environmentalists called for the protection of nature and the establishment of parks. When first undersea telephone link, COMPAC, arrived in 1963, there was a clash between the Canadian Overseas Telecommunications Service and environmentalists when the company cleared forest for cables connecting to the COMPAC system. The cable was ultimately landed with no problems, the cable coming ashore amidst logs, swerving uphill next to the Alberni Plywood Division.

Trans-Pacific Cable 4 was put in the water in 1991, only a few years after TPC-3 was laid, yet it doubled the capacity of the earlier system. As the first fiber cable that linked directly from the USA to Japan, it was also the last system to be landed on Canada's west coast. After it was withdrawn from service in 2003, the Port Alberni station ceased to operate transoceanic systems.
This cable, manufactured by Telcon and laid by the China Submarine Telegraph Company, was completed on June 11, 1871.

You might have come here in 1871, when the China Submarine Telegraph Cable company surfaced a cable from Singapore. Or, you might have come along the 1884 cable, brought ashore by the Eastern Extension company. Despite these outlets to British Empire, the city remained in the hands of the French, who did not lay their own cable until the turn of the twentieth century. It was the French colony of Cochinchina and as a port, a city, and a communications hub, became militarily, economically, and ideologically important for the following century. Indigenous rebel forces regularly fought bloody battles against colonization, as the French and Japanese squabbled over the city until its independence in 1954. During the Vietnam War, the U.S. and other western nations would back forces originating from Saigon in their fight against communist North Vietnam. Leaving the city during these years, transmission was slow: the government controlled the cable station and any international messages were delayed for at least an hour in order for the censors to approve them before they could be sent through the system.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: A trading post since the second century, the island of Singapore was a hub of exchange for Southeast Asia long before the British settled there in 1819. When the first underwater telegraph cable arrived forty years later, Singapore was a bustling port city, what one nineteenth-century cable survey called “that thriving halfway house between Europe and the East.” Although produced in a factory in London more than six thousand miles away, the Singapore-Muntok cable was insulated with the coagulated sap of trees native to the region. The Malays had used this substance, known as gutta-percha, for generations to make whips and other products. In the 1840s, a Scottish doctor stationed in Singapore took notice of the sap and brought it back to London. Gutta-percha made an ideal electrical insulator and became the material of choice in the cable industry.  By the time gutta-percha-encased wires populated Singapore's waters, demand had all but wiped out the local flora that made its transmissions possible.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value:

Chester G. Hearn, Circuits in the Sea: The Men, the Ships, and the Atlantic Cable. Westport, CT: Praeger Publishers, 2004. 10-11.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In September 1901, the Dutch East Indies government constructed a cable between Banjarmasin and Java as part of a new Dutch-German agreement “for the purpose of establishing telegraphic communication with their Colonial possessions in Asia.”

Known as the “River City,” Banjarmasin (once spelled Bandjermasin) is situated at the intersection of the Martapura and Barito rivers on Borneo’s southern coast. In the seventeenth century, the country’s rich natural resources—including gold, pepper, and gambier (a plant with medicinal properties)—were transported by river and sold in the natural harbor to Chinese, British, and Dutch traders. Native craftsmen were famous for their flat-bottomed wooden vessels, which carried goods through the city’s network of canals. After they secured a trade monopoly, the Dutch made Banjarmasin the capital of Borneo in the late 1700s. Soon thereafter, the electrical flows of telegraph communication joined the liquid and trade flows that defined the city’s pre-colonial history.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Fiber optic systems, which encode signals in light and send them down a thread of glass, have been in development since the early 1980s. Given the conservatism of the industry, the first international system was not put in place until 1986. The immense capacity of these systems have made possible the internet as we know it today.

Entering service in 1990 and since decommissioned, the Hong Kong-Japan-Korea (HJK) cable system connected Deep Water Bay, Hong Kong and Chikura, Japan with a branch to Jeju Island, South Korea. It was built by Fujitsu Limited (with AT&T as a subcontractor) and, along with the TPC-3, GPT, and HonTai cables, formed a “redundant fiber loop” in the South Pacific.

Entering service in March 1999, this optical cable connects the Philippine Long Distance Telephone Company’s station in Batangas with AT&T’s landing point in Guam, where connections are made to several Asia-U.S. networks. It was designed to complement and ease congestion along existing Asian and trans-Pacific cable systems.

The small town of Nasugbu, strategically located on the South China Sea only sixty miles from Metro Manila, is the largest network hub in the Philippines. In the 1990s, the Philippine Long Distance Telephone Company opened the country’s first international cable station, which towers over the palm trees and bamboo structures that line the beach. Just down the street is Globe Telecom’s newer facility, an anchor point for the Southeast Asia Japan cable system. Large walls surround both stations and the place where cables enter the water is unmarked. On their journey out to sea, they pass the remains of a Spanish galleon, sunk by the Dutch navy in 1600. Discovered in 1992, the shipwreck became one of the most important finds in underwater archeology. A replica, along with a museum and resort, were built on nearby Fortune Island but have since fallen into disrepair.

The Tanguisson Beach station, built to house American networks during the Cold War era, resembles an underground bunker. Entering, you descend several stories down a fortified stairwell and even then, can only access the equipment room once admitted through a secure metal door. Immediately inside the entrance is a decontamination chamber, a former precaution for nuclear attack, and now a storage closet. Everything inside is redundant in case the domestic infrastructure fails. Multiple, completely separated generators comprise backups for building power and air-conditioning units. Independent battery plants sustain the equipment. During the coaxial era, Tanguisson was staffed by at least two employees at all times, but was often occupied by many more. On the wall, you witness evidence of the community formed here: yearbook-style photos of all of the AT&T stations in the Pacific: Makaha, Keawa‘ula, Bandon, San Luis Obispo, and Manchester. Each has an image of the station, and photos of the people who worked there, with their name and position listed underneath, grouped as a school class would be. Photographs of the cable ships, AT&T cable landings, and maps of Guam decorate the walls. Due to the massive downsizings that have occurred since the 1980s, far fewer people work at Tanguisson today. The cable community, however, still exists.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: OPT

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: While early telegraph cables to Australia landed far outside Nouméa, the 2008 link to Sydney was brought into the industrial heart of New Caledonia’s capital and largest city. Owned by the Postal and Telecommunications Office, the station sits on a small, south-facing cove adjacent to a notoriously overcrowded prison and the French colony’s main container port, opened in 2006. Across the bay is a massive smelting plant that processes nearly a quarter of the global nickel supply. As container vessels depart with metal bound for Australia, Japan, and Europe, cruise ships arrive carrying tourists into the city. At the University of New Caledonia, located a short walk from the cable station, degrees are granted in French literature, network administration, and extractive metallurgy, among other subjects.

Oxford Falls is a center of coordination, a place where seemingly opposed forces depend on one another: human and non-human, wired and wireless, and major telecommunications competitors. A relatively rural area north of Sydney, Oxford Falls was a satellite gateway well before it was a hub for wired infrastructure. In 1987, the government-owned Overseas Telecommunication Commission selected this valley for a satellite earth station in part because the surrounding forest, densely vegetated with native species, naturally protected aerial signals from radiointerference. Eight years later, the earth station’s major competitor, Optus, set up a second facility just down the road. As nature shielded human communication and as competitors paved the way for one another, wireless forms also set the stage for wired links. In the years that followed, major international cable networks terminated in Oxford Falls, interconnecting with rather than eliminating the older satellite arrays.

Planned and built over the course of seven years, this cable sponsored by the New Caledonia Postal and Telecommunications Office (OPT-NC) joined the French territory to a hub in North Sydney in 2008. It’s named after the southern super-continent that broke away from Pangaea roughly 200 million years ago and which included what are now Africa, Australia, South America, and Antarctica. While it doesn’t bundle multiple continents, the cable did bring New Caledonia into the modern underwater network, boosting local connection speeds well beyond existing satellite links.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: Rostelecom,  KDDI

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The only station on the west coast of Honshu, Naoetsu was linked to Russia by coaxial cable in 1969, followed by optical lines in the 1990s and 2000s. But this was not the town’s first entry into exchange networks. As early as the ninth century, its harbor bustled with merchant ships carrying rice, salted salmon, and fabrics for protection against the wet and snowy climate, later expanding to accommodate steamships and cargo vessels. Naoetsu is also the birthplace of Maejima Hisoka, Japan’s first Minister of Communications and so-called father of the postal system. After studying British mail delivery in 1870, he returned to Japan and set up a network of sixty-five offices between Tokyo and Osaka. By 1881, there were more than five thousand.

It’s a typical grey day in Nakhodka. Looking out across the bay, you see large shipping vessels lingering beyond the oil rigs that dot the shore. Discovered in 1859 by a Russian warship seeking shelter from a storm, Nakhodka means “lucky find” in Russian. Despite its location on the edge of Siberia, the bay is relatively calm and ice-free, making it an optimal location for dropping anchor, as well as for surfacing cable systems. Nakhodka was the site for the landing of a telephone cable to Japan in 1969, followed by several fiber-optic links carrying internet traffic. As is true for many of the postwar systems, this station is a relocation, over 100 miles, from the previous urban telegraph cable landing in Vladivostok. Similarly, the Trans-Siberian railway’s eastern terminus was shifted to Nakhodka in the 1950s, when Soviet authorities closed Vladivostok to foreign shipping. Then the only open port in the Russian Far East, Nakhodka grew rapidly from its trade and communications industries. Today, the small city of 150,000 still supports circulations across the ocean: shipping and receiving, fish processing and canning, oil, and cable signals.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Wikipedia contributors, “Nakhodka,” Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia, accessed June 9, 2013, http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nakhodka.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Having built two previous cable systems across the Sea of Japan, Rostelecom and KDDI launched the dual-line Russia-Japan Cable Network in September 2008, only a few months after competing telecom operators established a northern link from Hokkaido to Sakhalin. Combined with Russia’s terrestrial cable system, RJCN boasts a latency of less than 200 milliseconds between Tokyo and London, faster than both Pacific/U.S. and Indian Ocean routes.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: Telekom Malaysia,  AT&T,  Starhub,  PLDT,  Communications Authority of Thailand,  airtel (Bharti),  Telstra,  Telkom Indonesia,  BT,  Eastern Telecom,  PT Indonesia Satellite Corp.,  Telecom New Zealand,  Viettel Corporation,  Saigon Postal Corporation,  Vietnam Telecom International,  Brunei International Gateway,  BayanTel

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: By the 1990s, capacity was filling up at Hong Kong’s major cable station, and the cable companies looked for a place to expand. Lantau Island, a few miles away from Hong Kong, seemed ideal. It was to be the site for major infrastructure developments during that period: a new Hong Kong airport, a trans-bay expressway, and the AsiaWorld theme park were placed in what was otherwise a sprawling, sparsely populated jungle. The station builders chose Tong Fuk, a small village on the island’s southern shore, for their landing. When they went to construct the station, however, the village leaders resisted, worried that the cable stations would disrupt the feng shui of the land and bring them bad fortune. The stations were ultimately placed there, but were careful not to infringe upon the nearby shrine.

You arrive in Baccuit Sur, a coastal neighborhood in the town of Bauang, near resorts, dive shops, and stands that sell grapes and guava-apple hybrids from local farms. The two main segments of the Asia-America Gateway fiber-optic system meet at Bauang’s cable station, forming a bridge between Southeast Asia and the Pacific. Before it catered to beachgoers and network traffic, this former Spanish colony was a site of violent conflict. Moro pirates invaded Bauang several times in the 1800s, leading the town to construct a defensive network of cylindrical stone watchtowers along the coast. And when Japan occupied the Philippines during the Second World War, Japanese troops clashed with the local resistance movement on Bauang’s otherwise calm shores.

In 1962, the balance of undersea cable power was shifting from British companies to the United States. The Keawa‘ula cable station had just been built on O‘ahu’s west shore to land the Commonwealth Pacific Cable. British transoceanic lines no longer stopped at Fanning Island, but rely on the United States. As such, its construction followed U.S. military specifications: it was located underground in a nuclear fallout shelter with walls that were feet thick. Arriving at this station today, you see an elegant set of steps up leading up to a front wall comprised of square glass blocks. One transmission engineer describes Keawa‘ula as a “palace.” Designed by a local Honolulu-based firm, the station's aboveground expansion was inspired by a visit from the CEO of Teleglobe Canada in the 1980s. With little space for gathering inside, the staff members at the time held their meeting in a small and cramped lunch room. Afterward, the CEO saw the station workers outside, joking around and hanging out in the trees like monkeys. In part inspired by the cable community, Teleglobe built a new, staff-friendly environment. The re-designed station grounded the communication hub in the heart of the cable family, yet left intact its Cold War foundations.

Asia-America Gateway (AAG), opened in 2009, was the first high-bandwidth optical cable to provide a direct link between Southeast Asia and California (via the Philippines, Guam, and Hawaii). Positioned further south than other trans-Pacific routes, AAG avoids the seismically active areas near Taiwan where earthquakes are known to cause cable disruptions.

Sanford Fleming and the Canadian Government mobilized arguments about security to establish the first transpacific cable system in 1902, creating a foundational route for all north-south Pacific traffic. This system mastered the scale of the globe: the Pacific Cable Board line between Bamfield, Canada and Fanning Island was then the longest undersea cable in the world. This system also required new expenditures for infrastructure and planning. A new 8,000 ton ship, the Colonia, had to be constructed specifically for the line.

There are only a few ways to get ashore at Norfolk Island. Rough sees batter the island’s high, rocky walls. There are no harbors or ports. Strong currents make entry difficult at the one feasible cable landing site, Anson Bay, and even here landslides can take out the hillside. Despite these difficulties, the island was determined to be the only feasible geographic location to land the first transpacific cable after it snaked down from Fiji and before it branched off to Australia and New Zealand. Norfolk’s inaccessibility had once made it an ideal location for a convict settlement, yet this had been closed almost fifty years prior to the cable’s arrival. Migrants from Pitcairn, the descendants of the Bounty mutineers, have taken up residence in the penal buildings. The island’s insularity coupled with a lack of traffic produced a set of unique connections. For a period of time, the cableman on night duty in Southport would send newspaper extracts to Norfolk Island, where they were typed up by the operator and “tacked up on a tree at the crossroads for all to read.” This news source was known as the “Tree of Knowledge.” By the 1920s, with the development of automatic relays, far fewer staff were needed on Norfolk.

Doubtless Bay, at the tip of New Zealand's North Island, was the landing site of the Pacific Cable Board's link from 1902 to 1912. The cable layers initially considered the Parengarenga Harbour, closer to the island's North Cape, but the location was too far from populated areas. Ahipara, on the west coast, was also considered, but this too was far from any existing telegraph lines. Although Doubtless Bay - far enough north, yet still possessing infrastructure - was established as a final middle ground, it was eventually replaced by Auckland as the entry point for New Zealand's northward-bound signal traffic. The remnants of the cable, rendered inoperational over a over a century ago, continues to surface periodically on the beach and pieces have been cut out of it for the regional museum.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: NTT,  China Telecom,  China Unicom,  Chunghwa Telecom,  KT,  Starhub,  LG Uplus,  China Mobile,  Viettel Corporation,  Vietnam Telecom International,  Global Transit,  Facebook

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Popular with surfers and backpackers, the small fishing village of Cherating lies approximately twenty miles north of Kuantan on the central east coast of Malaysia. Every spring and summer, leatherback sea turtles swim through the calm waters and lay their eggs on broad sand beaches lined with Casuarina trees. These same environmental conditions are well suited to underwater cable landings: sand is an accommodating medium for cable burial and there are no strong ocean currents to shift or expose cables once in place. Although cables have connected here since the 1990s, the current station was built as part of Telekom Malaysia’s investment in the APCN-2 system of the early 2000s. A single-story complex with pitched roofs set back from the road and surrounded by a security fence, the Cherating cable station is relatively unassuming. But a large communications tower, visible for miles, marks the site as a hub for signal traffic.

Busan is a major gateway for East Asian cable traffic, with five submarine networks interconnecting at this station. It is also where some of the best seaweed in South Korea is grown, one cableman tells you. Unfortunately, the boom in South Korean seaweed production, which comprises over half of the country’s aquaculture, doesn’t benefit international signal traffic. Dense seaweed forests immediately off Busan’s shore twist around ropes bordering the cable’s path. Harvesting them, fishermen come close to the country’s international communications lines. When building a new system, cable companies aren’t allowed to dig into the seabed, since this might disturb the fragile seaweed’s growth. Instead they carefully place each cable in a “mattress” before lowering it down into the crop.

In 2012, a consortium of telecom companies led by China Unicom signed a construction and maintenance agreement for the Asia-Pacific Gateway (APG) cable system, due to open in 2015. The system is specially routed to avoid areas prone to seismic activity while providing additional capacity along the region’s existing international networks.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: Telstra

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Bondi Beach is perhaps better known as a world famous surfing locale than as a hotspot for cable landing. Since the early twentieth century, however, Bondi has been the landing point for numerous telegraph, telephone, and fiber-optic cable systems. Located right near the center of Sydney, Bondi offers proximity for cable layers that seek to move in close to downtown markets. The most difficult part for cable companies is getting from the coastal beaches where cables land to Sydney's central cable station. Given the lack of duct space under the streets, this makes it difficult to lay new systems directly into major cities.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Jonathan Manthorpe, Forbidden Nation: A History of Taiwan (New York: Palgrave Macmillan, 2005), 147.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Midway between Taiwan and China, this chain of small islands is strategically important. As a result, even though the islands are sparsely populated, they have long been connected by communications networks. In 1887, the government landed a cable here, connecting to China on one side and to the rest of Taiwan on the other. Less than ten years later, the Chinese attacked and attempted to take possession of the islands, but were driven away by the Japanese, who were then occupying Penghu and later, all of Taiwan. The Japanese would remain in Penghu throughout the first half of the twentieth century, laying cables that linked China and Taiwan. While the connected cities grew busy with international trade, the Penghu Islands remained apart from the action, with most ships and signal traffic merely passing through.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1901-1950,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed August 19, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1901.htm.
Jonathan Manthorpe, Forbidden Nation: A History of Taiwan (New York: Palgrave MacMillan, 2009), 147.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In 1887, a cable was laid from Anping harbor in Tainan, then the capital of Taiwan, to the Penghu archipelago on the order of Liu Mingchuan, an official in the Qing dynasty. The lack of trade between Tainan and Penghu meant that the cable “was of little importance to the commercial world,” explains American diplomat James W. Davidson. Yet “it was of great value from a political standpoint, the strategic importance of the [Penghu] islands demanding that they should be in communication with the capital.” This political value was short-lived, however, since the capital was moved north to Taipei later that year. Tainan has seen many such political fluctuations in its history. The Dutch established a fort here in the early 1600s, which was later taken over by Chinese military leaders, the Qing, the Japanese, and finally the Republic of China. Reconstituted under each new ruler, Tainen was nicknamed “The Phoenix City.”

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value:
Jonathan Manthorpe, Forbidden Nation: A History of Taiwan. New York: Pelgrave Macmillan, 2005. 147.
James W. Davidson, The Island of Formosa Past and Present: History, People, Resources, and Commercial Prospects. London and New York: Macmillan & Co., 1903. 247.
China Imperial Maritime Customs, Decennial Reports on the Trade, Navigation, Industries, etc. of the Ports Open to Foreign Commerce in China and Corea and on the Condition and Development of the Treaty Port Provinces, 1882-91. London: The Statistical Department of the Inspectorate General of Customs, 1893. 467.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: Reliance Globalcom,  PCCW,  Telstra

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Waves crash up against a thick seawall that spans the coast of Toucheng. Much of the shore here in northeast Taiwan is comprised of sand rock, eroded by ocean waves and monsoon winds. Spectacular surface formations are cut into the sedimentary rock, some locals observe that these even resemble tofu. Yet the erosion here is not entirely natural. The presence of manmade structures on 56% of Taiwan’s coast, this seawall included, has sped up the disappearance of the coast. These structures interrupt the flow of sand, causing it to accumulate on one side and to quickly erode on the other. The nearby Toucheng beach, which once stretched for two kilometers, is now severely diminished, and the coast has retreated up to 100 meters inland. This seawall keeps the shoreline intact for both waves and cable stations, but provides an additional challenge for cable laying. Companies have to bore a hole through the thick walls in order to thread their networks through.

A seventy-foot whale skeleton occupies a public plaza in central Wada. This small town outside Tokyo is also home to a dedicated landing station for the FLAG North Asian Loop cable, a kind of underwater skeletal system for communication in Asia. While the station is relatively new, whaling has been central to the culture and economy since the early 1600s. Today, Wada is one of only two places in Japan where it’s still permitted, and efforts are made to keep the tradition alive despite international bans. Every June, local schoolchildren gather to watch the first whale being brought ashore and butchered, followed by a community meal of fried whale, rice, and watermelon. Optical cables land far more discretely but in growing numbers along this stretch of the outer Bōsō Peninsula, now crowded with cable stations. Although across the Pacific, cable companies have to worry about people digging up their land lines, the coastal area of Wada is safe. Because of the local culture, one cableman says, people stick by their agreements to stay off the route that the telecommunications company bought. As a result, they have only needed to install a single line between the cable station and the landing point, compared to redundant lines that must be extended everywhere else.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/title.value: FLAG North Asia Loop/REACH North Asia Loop

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: FLAG North Asian Loop a.k.a. Reach North Asian Loop, jointly developed by India’s Global Cloud Xchange (formerly FLAG Telecom) and China’s Reach Global Services, has one of the largest cable capacities in Asia. The system’s two fiber loops connect Hong Kong, Taiwan, South Korea, and Japan and were completed in 2001 and 2002.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: France Telecom,  SingTel,  Telecom Italia Sparkle,  Tata Communications,  PT Indonesia Satellite Corp.,  Telekom Malaysia,  airtel (Bharti),  Sri Lanka Telecom,  Etisalat,  Saudi Telecom,  Communications Authority of Thailand,  Tunisia Telecom,  Verizon Business,  PCCW,  Pakistan Telecommunications Company Ltd.,  Telecom Egypt

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: When it was finished in December 2005, the consortium-owned Southeast Asia-Middle East-Western Europe 4 cable provided both additional bandwidth and greater redundancy along the bulk of the previous-generation SeaMeWe-3 line between the Mediterranean and Singapore. SeaMeWe-3, however, extends significantly further to points in China, Japan, Australia, the U.K., and Germany, among others.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: NTT,  China Telecom,  China Unicom,  Chunghwa Telecom,  KT,  Starhub,  LG Uplus,  China Mobile,  Viettel Corporation,  Vietnam Telecom International,  Global Transit,  Facebook

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Built in the 1970s, Nanhui station was the first landing site for international coaxial cables in China. Early signals surfaced on the muddy shores of Nanhui district, then mostly farmland, roughly thirty miles southeast of central Shanghai. Now the area is almost unrecognizable, transformed by rapid industrialization that has displaced many of its former inhabitants. Large-scale development projects have even altered the local geography, continuing a process begun millennia ago when Nanhui was formed by silt deposited at the mouth of the Yangtze River. New cables pass by a huge artificial island that contains the recently constructed Shanghai deep-water container port, linked to the mainland by a twenty-mile bridge. And just east of the station, an entire city for 800,000 is being built from scratch on land reclaimed from Hangzhou Bay.

The Australia-Papua New Guinea cable was laid between Port Moresby and Cairns in 1975, becoming operational in 1976. The cable, like many others of this generation, outlasted its design life, serving Papua New Guinea until it was replaced by APNG-2 in 2006.

Landing at Ela Beach, it’s hard to believe you are in one of the most dangerous places in the Pacific. Blue-green waters lap up against the white sands, strewn with seaweed. Papuan children splash in the water and linger under palm trees. Traveling a bit farther up the coast, past a cargo terminal, to the Poreporena Villages, you find an entire shanty-town built on rotting stilts. The water here is less clear and the rocky beach is strewn with trash. Port Moresby, the capital city of Papua New Guinea, is riddled with poverty. Raskol gangs, known for armed robberies, roam the streets and clash with the police, who have an equally violent reputation. The murder rate in this city of 250,000 is three times that of London. Just across the Coral Sea from Australia, the city has been the entry way for Papua New Guinea’s cable communications since 1976 – an infrastructure that many had hoped would contribute to development and better lives for the country’s citizens.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: David Fickling, “Raskol gangs rule world's worst city,” The Guardian, accessed June 22, 2013, http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2004/sep/22/population.davidfickling.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Even as far back as the nineteenth century, cables have been used as ways to open up developing areas by linking them into modern communications systems.

Surfacing at Whitford Beach, you are careful not to be hit by one of the sixteen-foot tall waves also making its way to the shore. This beach is beautiful and active: the hollow and powerful waves draw surfers from throughout the area and the soft sands bring visitors to lounge, fly kites, and ride horses along this sunny stretch of land. Several major international cables have also landed here, connecting Australia to Asia. About ten miles inland is the Perth International Telecommunications Centre (PITC), which occupies 710 square acres of flat, dry land in a rural suburb. Since 1986, the center has handled much of Australia's signal traffic. With its own power plant, and a 15-meter diameter antenna for communicating with spacecrafts, PITC is a stark contrast to the brick house on the shores of Cottesloe that welcomed the trans-Indian-Ocean telegraph cable in 1901.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1951-2000,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed June 22, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1951.htm.
“Whitfords Beach,” Surfing in Perth City, Australia, http://www.wannasurf.com, accessed June 22, 2013, http://www.wannasurf.com/spot/Australia_Pacific/Australia/WA/Perth_City/whitfords_beach/.

“Whitfords Outer Reefs or Seal Island,” Surfing in Perth City, Australia, http://www.wannasurf.com, accessed June 22, 2013, http://www.wannasurf.com/spot/Australia_Pacific/Australia/WA/Perth_City/Whitfords_beach_outer_reefs/.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Although it was originally a swampy wetland, Ancol is now something like the Disneyworld of Indonesia, bustling with rides, beach-goers, and children. Perched on the northern edge of East Java, in Jakarta Bay, it lies in between the upscale waterfront neighborhood of Pantai Mutiara and a busy international ferry terminal. The spot draws visitors from Jakarta and nearby Javanese cities, as well as many who cross the Java and South China Seas, coming to vacation from Sumatra, Singapore, or the Philippines. Cables have trafficked signals into the area since 1859, when an undersea cable connected from a neighborhood just south of Ancol to Singapore and the rest of Asia.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1951-2000,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed July 19, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1951.htm.
Telegeography, “Submarine Cable Map,” accessed July 19, 2013, www.submarinecablemap.com.
“Ancol Cable Landing Station,” Submarine Cable Networks: The World of Submarine Cable Systems and Networks, accessed July 19, 2013, http://www.submarinenetworks.com/stations/asia/indonesia/ancol.
James Bamford, The Shadow Factory: The Ultra-Secret NSA from 9/11 to the Eavesdropping on America (New York: Doubleday, 2008).

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: 1894-?; Telcon; Eastern Extension, Australasia China Telegraph Co; Scotia (see AtlanticCable.com)

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: An 1894 article about the cable in The Singapore Free Press and Mercantile Advertiser observes that this system, a duplicate route between Singapore and Hong Kong, "is a work almost of supererogation, certainly one not required or justified by the existing traffic." At the point a single cable could still carry all of the traffic to and from China. Instead, the aim was "to give greater assurance and security to communication between India and Europe and between [Singapore] and China." By connecting the main Naval base at Hong Kong with the other colonies (and stopping only on British territory, they predicting that the new cable would "materially increase the security of British interests in the Far East."

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Cable laid into Victoria Harbor, opposite government offices.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: A tiny island off the northeastern coast of Malaysia, Labuan was the site of important British coal fields during the colonial era. Nestled safely within the Brunei Bay, the spot was ideal for the traffic of signals, ships, and resources. Labuan became a stopping point for the cable connecting Singapore and Hong Kong, which it existing midway between, in 1894. British ships also stopped here as they traversed the South China Sea: the harvesting of coal made it both an export center and a fueling point for the Imperial Navy. This flat, green island remained relatively unsettled by the British, who used it almost exclusively for its ore and harbor. Today, the island’s development continues to depend on its ocean-going history. Scuba divers come here to explore old sunken ships and oil and gas companies drill offshore, harvesting modern energy sources.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1845-1900,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed August 12, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1850.htm.
Commander of the Guard Ship, Ed. S. T., “Labuan – Coal Discoveries,” Hongkong Register, April 27, 1847, accessed August 12, 2013, http://trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/31752854.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: “The trees obscure the houses near the beach, making it difficult to distinguish the port,” warns a British steamship captain in 1910. His description of Buleleng also notes the twin telegraph cables connecting the town to other Dutch colonies across the Bali Sea and to the nearby island province of West Nusa Teggara. In the 1840s, the Dutch performed a series of military operations in northern Bali before establishing a formal colony in Buleleng in 1882. It was their first on the island and the center of the new colonial administration. Although camouflaged by trees, the Buleleng harbor was a highly visible point on the map of international trade. By the late nineteenth century, dozens of European ships and hundreds of local vessels carrying rice, coffee, spices, vanilla, and tobacco came through the port every year.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value:
U.S. Hydrographic Office, Port Facilities No. 6: Indian Ocean. Washington: U.S. Hydrographic Office under the authority of the Secretary of the Navy, 1911. 8.
Robert Cribb and Audrey Kahin, Historical Dictionary of Indonesia (Second Edition). Lanham, MD: Scarecrow Press, 2004. 40.
Robert Cribb, Historical Atlas of Indonesia. Surrey: Curzon, 2000. 120.
Willard A. Hanna, Bali Chronicles. Singapore: Periplus, 2004. 128.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Like so many Indonesian cities, Makassar developed under the influence of European spice trades starting in the 16th century. The Dutch came in the 17th century and the cables began to arrive in the late 19th century, connecting this city with Bali in 1888, Balikpapan in 1905, and then with Java and Central Sulawesi in 1913. Arriving along the cable at the turn of the twentieth century, you witness the height of Dutch development: they had captured, rebuilt, and renamed the city’s central fort. The new “Fort Rotterdam” looked very much like its namesake, with manicured lawns and large stone buildings with pitched red roofs. The walled city that developed around the fort was a hub for the copra, rattan, pearls, trepang, and sandalwood trade, and enslaved local people for businessmen. Although Joseph Conrad called Makassar “the prettiest and perhaps, cleanest looking of all the towns in the islands,” such beauty reflected colonial interests.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: Pacnet

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Landing at one of two designated sites on the northern and southern coasts of Changi, you make your way inland to a cluster of stations that form East Singapore’s primary cable hub. Today, the area is known for its major international airport complex, which includes a cactus garden, butterfly habitat, and what will soon be the world’s largest indoor waterfall. But this cutting-edge cable and aviation crossroads has a dark history. The British established a military base at Changi in the early 1900s when the peninsula was still mostly swampland and forests of tall “chengei” trees. During its occupation of Singapore in World War II, Japan used the compound to imprison thousands of captured Allied soldiers. (The prison was rebuilt in the 1990s and now has a death-row detention center.) Even the northern beaches where cables come ashore, a popular spot for picnics and watersports, were the setting for a brutal 1942 massacre of Chinese Singaporeans thought to be anti-Japanese.

EAC-C2C represents the merger of the EAC (East Asia Crossing) and C2C (City-to-City) cable networks, completed in 2007 by Pacnet. Together, they form Asia’s largest privately owned cable system with a total of seventeen landing sites across Japan, Korea, China, Taiwan, Hong Kong, the Philippines, and Singapore.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: A futuristic cable station sits next to the expansive wetlands of the Dongtan national wildlife sanctuary. Signals arrive through major underwater networks, while swans, cranes, spoonbills, shorebirds, and many species of fish stop here along their migratory routes. Like the landing station, Chongming Island’s salt-water marshes and tidal flats are transitional zones that mediate between land and sea. Although it feels rural, the island is only twenty miles from central Shanghai and is connected by a freeway. Visitors fill the tree-lined boardwalks that crisscross the reserve, observing the local fauna. Meanwhile, data is surveilled as it passes through the station: a white sign with red text marks the presence of underground cables and bears the name “PLA Unit 61398,” a group believed to engage in electronic monitoring and cyber-attacks against the U.S..

Stretching a total of 24,000 miles between 39 landing sites, Southeast Asia-Middle East-Western Europe 3 (SeaMeWe-3) is more than twice as long as its intercontinental predecessor, SeaMeWe-2. The optical cable system was commissioned in 2000 by an international consortium of nearly 100 corporate investors.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The Kuala Muda station in Penang, commissioned in the early 1980s by Telekom Malaysia (TM), was the country’s first landing site for underwater telephone cables. As the westernmost point on the Malay Peninsula, the state of Penang made a logical terminus for the Indian Ocean Commonwealth (IOCOM) cable from Chennai, completed in 1981. While Penang’s nineteenth-century telegraph connections surfaced in the bustling heart of colonial George Town, IOCOM and subsequent cables landed ten miles north in a comparably remote area where the Muda River flows into the Malacca Strait. By placing the station on the outskirts, TM minimized the risk of cable damage from anchors and trawls of passing ships. Today, the company controls all four of Malaysia’s cable hubs (and five smaller stations), similarly positioned in fishing villages and beach towns on the urban fringe.

Today, Medan is the fourth largest city in Indonesia and the second busiest port. Huge shipping boats slide through the grey water, alongside long dark piers. Here, they are filled with tobacco, palm oil, tea, and rubber, before being sent back out through the Strait of Malacca. While goods flow out, people and signals flow in. The city itself is modernized and notoriously ethnically diverse, its industries requiring fast technologies and drawing a range of immigrant workers. In many ways, it is also a pilgrimage destination. Since 1906, religious devotees have traveled here to visit The Great Mosque of Medan. Today, visitors come from around Asia to feed their tastes as well as their souls: the city is known for its myriad cuisines, from Javanese cuisine, to Batak pork, Chinese noodles, and Indian curries. In 1999, a cable surfaced here connecting from Singapore, through Medan, to Penang. Medan had been an essential node in this path before – in the early 1890s, coincident with the city’s growth as a tobacco exporter, a telegraph cable was laid here connecting to Penang and Acheen. As trade continued and industry grew, so too did the information transiting the city.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: As you approach Colombo, Ceylon (present-day Sri Lanka) in 1903, your travel guide tells you: “its appearance is extremely picturesque: a fine undulating country, well wooded to the water’s edge and fringed by cocoa-nut trees; lofty verdant ranges tower in the distance, covered with groves of talipat and other palms.” Centrally positioned in the Indian Ocean, Colombo was a key trade port long before the colonial era. In the early 1500s, the Portuguese established a fort and trading post to capitalize on the island’s abundant cinnamon crops. After a brief Dutch occupation, Colombo was ceded to the British and became the capital of British Ceylon. To facilitate faster communication to London, a submarine cable was brought to the island via the Middle East in 1913, connecting to a new Central Telegraph Office in a three-story wood building near the harbor. Messages could now travel between the two cities in as little as thirty minutes, a savings of nearly four hours compared to older land-based routes through India. Today, messages transit in only milliseconds from five cable systems that land in the Colombo area.

Alongside a cable to Tschifu, he Russian post and telegraph service laid a cable from Port Arthur to Sasebo, in Japan. Only five years later, both were handed over to the Imperial Chinese Telegraph Company.

Southwest of Dairen, at the tip of the Liaodong Peninsula, Port Arthur was an important Russian naval port at the turn of the twentieth century. It has a naturally protected southern harbor, allowing ships safe anchor throughout the year. In 1900, the Russians landed two telegraph cables here, one connecting south across the Yellow Sea to Tschifu, China and one connecting the longer distance west to Sasebo. This communications node would soon become Russia’s Achilles’ Heel: the cables were cut and intercepted by the Japanese leading up to and during the Russo-Japanese War.  Unable to receive reports or warnings, Port Arthur was then surprised when Japanese ships attacked. The Japanese took control of Port Arthur and from here were able to wage a successful war for the control of Manchurian land and sea. Unrest may have started even earlier, however: in the year before the war, cable ships record trips to repair breaks in the Port Arthur – Tschifu cable, due to “willful cutting.”

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Sasebo became an essential node for military communications at the turn of the twentieth century. This Japanese port is about 100 miles south of the southern tip of Korea, across the ocean from Shanghai. The town had been a small fishing village until the Meiji Period, when it quickly became an important naval base because of its protected, nearly land-locked, deep harbor. In 1898, a major railway station was opened here, anticipating the other traffic to come. Cables came in from Port Arthur, and out across the East China Sea to Dairen and Tsingtau. The town grew up around the transiting traffic, becoming a busy port and a wireless station. Like many other hubs in the Pacific, its connectivity would become a liability in future years. The wireless station here is believed to have broadcasted the message to attack Pearl Harbor during World War II. Four years later, Sasebo suffered severe bombing by allied forces, and was on the list of potential targets for the dropping of the atom bomb.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Shantou is a hub in four international cable networks, all built since the late 1990s. From your point of arrival on Longhu Beach, this state-of-the-art China Telecom facility could be mistaken for one of the many resort hotels that line the waterfront. Yet the new technology and luxury tourism of Shantou lies only twenty miles from Guiyu, a town that has been called “the electronic-waste capital of the globe.” Every year, the city receives over 1.5 million pounds of discarded computers and other electronics, most of it from overseas. Tens of thousands of laborers strip cables and dismantle circuit boards to extract valuable metals, but the toxic byproducts of these machines have devastated the workers’ health and surrounding environment.

The consortium-owned Southeast Asia Japan Cable (SJC) runs from Singapore to Japan, with branch connections to Thailand, Brunei, the Philippines, Hong Kong, and China. Intense demand along the communication route prompted capacity upgrades less than a year after it was built in 2013.

The Japan-Siberia Cable (JASC), laid in 1969, was a true postwar international collaboration. The cable was manufactured in part by Japan's Ocean Cable Company and in part by the United States's Underseas Cable Corporation (all of whose previous cables had been supplied to the US military). The cable was then laid by both the Japanese ship KDD Maru with assistance from the Dutch Great Northern Telegraph Company. This kind of collaboration was a hallmark of the analogue era. It operated long beyond its system design life (which was only 20 years) up until 1996, when it was withdrawn from service and used for earthquake research,

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The South Africa-Far East (SAFE) cable system, built in 2002 by a U.S. company, traverses the Indian Ocean on a path similar to the one taken by Portuguese explorers in the fifteenth century. By joining the SAT-3/WASC cable at Melkbosstrand, South Africa, SAFE provides a direct optical fiber link between Western Europe and Malaysia.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: Pacnet

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In 1900, the village of Naic in Cavite Province was joined to an offshore island by underwater telegraph cable as part of a U.S. Army Signal Corps operation to network the area around Manila. A century later, Naic became a landing site for EAC-C2C, bringing it into direct communication with the U.S. and several Asian countries. Owned by the Philippine Long Distance Telephone Company (PLDT), the station is located on the town’s outskirts near farmland, subdivisions, and a vast new horseracing complex with stables for 800 thoroughbreds. Even though they are broadcast online, spectators travel from as far as Manila to witness the races first-hand, a popular activity in the Philippines since the late nineteenth century. Some have even described the local telecommunications market, dominated by PLDT and Globe Telecom, as a two-horse race.

Before Hong Kong was handed back to China, one author observed that it was a “center of espionage, a hive of spies,” with up to 5,000 intelligence agents seeking information for countries around the world. In 1977, the British GCHQ built a satellite base at Chung Hom Kok, on Hong Kong’s less populated southern coast. For over a decade, the satellite base, code-named “Project Kittiwake,” was a center for monitoring Chinese communications and nuclear tests. It was reportedly critical for scanning communications about events including the Tiananmen Square massacre in 1989 and the break-up of the Soviet Union in 1991. When Hong Kong was transferred back to China, Project Kittiwake was moved and the site razed, leaving little for the Chinese to see. At the turn of the century, the Chinese government invested in Chung Hom Kok’s external communications – it was designated a “telecentre” for the development of satellite and submarine connections. Today a new undersea cable station, poised on the edge of a hill and overlooking small fishing boats that dot the waters, still monitors traffic. Rather than intercepting signals sent through the air, communications are now filtered before they are allowed to enter mainland China.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: Softbank Telecom,  NTT,  Telstra,  Verizon Business,  AT&T

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: You can journey to the village of Maruyama along cables from the U.S., Australia, or various sites in Southeast Asia. But upon reaching the station, you may feel as if you’ve traveled even farther—and back in time. Across the road is Rosemary Park, a detailed replica of a sixteenth-century English town. Built in 1997 by British architects, the tourist attraction includes a working windmill, formal gardens, a duck pond, and a recreation of Shakespeare’s childhood home, complete with lifelike statues and time-specific furnishings. Shakespeare referenced rosemary in his plays, and Maruyama is known for producing this and other herbs. While the park looks to the past, the modern cable station is one of Japan’s most popular landing sites. Both enact a kind of virtual transit to far-off locales.

The Australia-Japan Cable (AJC) links the two countries via Guam. When it was completed in 2001, it became “Australia’s largest connection yet to the global information highways,” according to an industry newsletter. The cable reaches depths of over 9,000 meters and forms a “collapsed ring” structure with twin lines spanning each leg of the system. A private company owned by Japanese and Australian telecoms was set up to design, build, and operate the cable until its projected retirement in 2026.

The Okinawa - Luzon - Hong Kong cable, like others of this period, was given an acronym that combined the first letters of the places that were connected: OLUHO. It was not until the fiber-optic period and the break-up of the consortium system that this naming practice began to shift to use more symbolic and less descriptive terms.

A 12th-century sea wall lines the edge of a small village where cables land. Locals come here to take in the panorama, looking east across the ocean. The clear seawater carries you up to white, rocky beaches, abutted by deep green brush leading into steep hills and low forests. The history of this village stretches back hundreds of years, when the sea wall and castle were built, forming the administrative and cultural center of the area. Yet the remoteness of the village made it appealing to cable companies during the coaxial period. After the destruction of World War II, companies surfaced cables far away from urban centers, like Okinawa City, which might be potential targets. In the 1970s and 1980s, a number of important international cables were landed here in Gushikami, making this rural land a submarine communications hub. More recently, the abandoned TPC-2 cable to Guam was revived for geophysical observations rather than telephone calls.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: For roughly two decades beginning in the late 1970s, this small village in the northwest Philippines was linked to the urban centers of Singapore, Hong Kong, and Okinawa. By 1980, Currimao was considered one of the largest and most advanced cable hubs in the world. But when the Asia-America Gateway system was being built in the early 2000s, the Philippine Long Distance Telephone Company selected a landing site more than a hundred miles south in the province of La Union, closer to Metro Manila. As quickly as it appeared, Currimao faded from the network map. Today it is perhaps best known for a series of coral rock formations, shaped by the ocean into dramatic caverns and spires over thousands of years.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Vladivostok is located at the south-easternmost tip of Russia, on the hills that rise at the head of the Zoltoy Rog Bay. The harbor’s name means “Golden Horn,” and references a similarly shaped harbor in Constantinople. Both cities grew up on the edge of their states and became important ending and beginning points for travel, shipping, and communication. In the early 1870s, when the Great Northern Telegraph Company established a cable landing at this site, the city was a busy trading port with a shipbuilding yard, which welcomed new settlers. Vladivostok’s first street was built in 1871, winding from the bay uphill to the wooden and stone residences that were rapidly appearing throughout the city. That same year the cable arrived, connecting Russia to Nagasaki and on to Shanghai. The telegraph office sat in a stately three-story office building at the corner of two major streets. By the turn of the twentieth-century, Vladivostok had developed into a modern city with tall buildings, shops, and hotels. The Trans-Siberian Railway, built at the same time, terminated in Vladivostok, connecting this easternmost edge of Russia to Moscow. Today, Vladivostok is the largest Russian port on the Pacific Ocean and is a busy city of about 500,000 people. People and goods still ebb and flow through this bay. The Russky Bridge, completed in 2012, is the largest cable-stayed bridge in the world, hovering over the Eastern Bosphorus Strait and connecting Vladivostok to Russky Island.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Although it started out as a small farm town, Shanghai grew into an important and busy port during the Qing Dynasty. In 1842, after the British defeated the Chinese in the first Opium War, Shanghai became a treaty port, occupied by British forces and open for international trade. Throughout the end of the 19th and beginning of the 20th centuries, the city grew rapidly. Tall municipal buildings and three-story stone houses with red roofs lined the wide and busy streets. The ports were congested with naval and trade ships from Britain, France, and Japan. The first telegraph cable arrived in 1871, connecting the city to Singapore and Hong Kong. As the cable was laid up the Yangtze River to Shanghai, men armed with rifles patrolled it to stop sailors from throwing anchor and severing the connection. By 1916, ten more cables - sponsored by a range of governments and militaries - had landed here, linking to Japan, Russia, Yap, the Philippines, and other Chinese ports.
