http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The Danish Great Northern Telegraph Company was a key player in the early telegraph network. The company was able to fund a system connecting parts of Europe and Asia in part due to the desire of Russia and other nations to have a secure communications route that ran independently of British links.

Completed in early 1906, the Yokohama-Bonin cable was part of a system linking Japan and the United States, with stopovers on several Pacific islands. As the journal Telegraph Age reports that year: “Bonin has recently been connected to Yokohama by a cable of English manufacture which the Japanese government has been laying with its own cable-ship, the Okinawa Maru. . . . The work was finished in twelve days without the least hitch, and the signals through the cable when laid were excellent.”

The port of Yokohama was a modest fishing village until the 1850s, when it was opened to foreign trade under pressure from the U.S.. Rapid development followed, transforming Yokohama into an international center of commerce. Japan’s first overland telegraph line linked Yokohama’s Court House station with neighboring Tokyo in 1869. Thirty-five years later, a submarine cable arrived from the Bonin Islands, bringing the city into communication with San Francisco more than 5,000 miles away. But the Great Kantō earthquake of 1923 devastated the city, including its nascent cable infrastructure. As a local newspaper reports, a tsunami swallowed boats in the harbor, fires swept through the streets, and “the telegraph building, in which most of the wires radiating to all parts of the island terminated, was completely demolished, leaving the telegraph system in a hopeless condition.” Yokohama was soon rebuilt, only to suffer more damage during the air raids of World War II.

On some islands, even finding a shore on which to land one’s cable is a fraught process. Located about 1000 miles south east of Japan, the Bonin Islands have steep coastlines that make landing difficult. Rocky mountainsides rise up from the blue-green sea, gradually turning from stone into lush greenery higher in the sky. In some spots, small strips of sand slice between the ocean and the hills. In the early 1900s, a cable landed on one of these remote beaches, connecting Guam (and thereby the United States) to Japan. The Japanese had claimed the land only a few decades earlier, and about forty settlers made their homes on the previously uninhabited islands. The American company sent British ships and workers here to land the cable, all of whom were tentatively but amicably received. Like the small beaches that marry the water and land, the islands served as the tiny but essential solder point between the US and Japan, mediating communication between these two distant societies.

Lionel Berners Cholmondeley, M.A., The History of the Bonin Islands: From the Year 1827 to the Year 1976 (London: Constable & Co. Ltd., 1915), accessed July 10, 2013, http://mysite.du.edu/~ttyler/ploughboy/boninchol.htm.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Walking around this cable landing, you take care not to fall in the ditches carved into the landscape. Trash clutters the cable landing area, and nearby, shots are fired at the end of Rifle Range Road. The station at Vatuwaqa, like so many others, was built in a largely industrial, suburban area just north of a major city, Suva. Yet unlike many cable stations, it is a place where people as well as signals come together. Men who work for Fiji's international telecommunications company are hanging out around the station. A dog lazily watches the front gate. Inside is a room constructed specifically for teleconferencing. Visiting, you find a sense of camaraderie and hospitality among the cable workers -- this is a place for meeting. In the courtyard, a monument commemorates the site's development as a satellite earth station, the landing point of the ANZCAN cable, and later, the Southern Cross system.
In 1932, the shore end of the cable was moved north from Wellington to Muriwai Beach, outside of Auckland. As New Zealand's commercial traffic moved northward, so did the cables.

Wandering on New Zealand’s west coast, you find a coaxial cable extending out from a sand bank, over a small pond of water, and back into the beach before it heads to Sydney. Aquatic creatures have incorporated its eroding armor and still strong copper core into their home. Old cables dating to the telegraph era have surfaced on this beach: the first international link landed over a century ago, in 1912. Cost-cutting during the Depression prompted the cable company to re-locate a second link, formerly in Wellington, here in 1932. From Muriwai cables extend inland over twenty miles to the growing city of Auckland. This terrestrial path is almost as fraught as the surf-beaten shores of Muriwai. In 1952, incorrectly gauging the location of the cable system, a road grader severed the international network for five hours. After this, the cable companies ensured that the network was extensively marked for the local community.

“On December 15,” declares a U.S. trade report, “the Eastern Telegraph Co.’s new cable from Penang to Colombo was established and its new cable system thrown open to traffic with London and with the Far East.” This 1913 cable was part of a much longer 12,000-mile connection between Lands End, England and Hong Kong (via Suez, Aden, Colombo, Penang, and Singapore). By avoiding slower overland lines and stopping points where a message has to be deciphered and retransmitted, the submarine cable greatly increased the speed and reliability of communication between Britain and its settlements in Asia.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Was located at 44 Northam Road, now Jalan Sultan Ahmad Shah.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In George Town at the turn of the 19th century you witness the beginnings of a modern city. The streets are lined with warehouses and ghauts, wide steps leading from the street to the water. Banks, trading areas, and emporium stores are beginning to appear along Beach Street. Since its founding by the British East India Company in 1786, the town has grown into a bustling trading port and commercial center. George Town has been built on water: its commercial center stands on a swampy wetland that was leveled and filled in the early 1800s. Seeing that this was precarious, English settlers built their bungalows high up on top of Penang Hill, forbidding natives to do the same. The settlers’ wealthy Chinese business partners were allowed to build in the middle part of the hill. The cable – part of the emerging modern city – surfaces close to the water, but ultimately connected those who lived far above it.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1845-1900,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed June 22, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1850.htm.
Visions of Penang Archives Online (My Heritage My Penang), accessed June 22, 2013, http://www.visionsofpenang.com.my

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: This 300-mile cable connects northern Japan to Russia’s terrestrial cable system, providing a shorter path between Japan and Europe compared to southern oceanic routes. It was completed in 2008 and is jointly owned by Japan’s NTT Corporation and TransTelekom of Russia.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: NTT,  TTK

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The remote village of Ishikari flourished in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries as a center of salmon fishing. One of its oldest standing structures is a 1694 shrine dedicated to the fish deity Same-sama. But as catches steadily declined in the 1900s, Ishikari expanded to become a shipping and communications gateway for the larger neighboring city of Sapporo. The first ship to arrive in the new harbor in 1982 was the Blanca Rainier from Sakhalin carrying 3,500 tons of raw timber. A ceremony held the next day marked the port’s entry into international freight circuits. Twenty-six years later, a fiber optic cable was laid along the same path, joining Russian and Japanese networks. Today, Ishikari is by far Japan’s northernmost cable station and the only landing site on the island of Hokkaido.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: Softbank Telecom,  NTT,  Telstra,  Verizon Business,  AT&T

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: This northern suburb of Auckland, New Zealand, has been an outlet for northward communications for more than a century. In 1912, after a new Chief Post Office was opened in central Auckland, the Pacific Cable Board re-directed their cable from rural Doubtless Bay to Takapuna Beach. The workers from the station came with the cable, and the cable station was set up on in the Post Office, consolidating networks formerly distributed across the land. As the cable continued to function without major disruptions, networks in the following decades were routed through the suburban beach. When the Southern Cross internet cable was set up in 2000, it too landed on the Takapuna shore. In the cable industry, the prevailing logic is to go with the tried and true.

The Hawai'i-2 telephone cable was the second link between the United States mainland and Hawai'i. Extended in 1964, it connected to a transpacific link that shuttled signals onward to Japan. For the system, a new station was constructed on O'ahu's west shore, which would become a critical hub for internet signals half a century later.

Heading inland to the Makaha cable station, you surface in a parking lot, in a manhole barely visible under the dirt. Along the beaches to the south of this town reside hundreds of houseless people. O‘ahu’s west shore is home to one of the state’s largest native communities and largest homeless population. In Makaha alone, 32% of its residents live in poverty. Yet, the west shore is also a transit point for a large percentage of the state’s international signal traffic. Since the 1960s, almost all of the island’s coaxial and fiber-optic cables have terminated at three cable stations along this short 30-kilometer stretch. The seemingly divergent histories of telecommunications success and economic deprivation in the area are intertwined, linked to the area's long-standing military occupation. Weapons testing sites and military installations, such as the Lualualei Naval Reservation and the Schofield Barracks, displaced residents from the west shore’s inland valleys. At the same time, the U.S. military was once one of the biggest customers of the cable networks, giving them both an economic boost and a layer of protection when they were set up during the Cold War.

AT&T has been integral to the laying of submarine cables since the 1950s. During the Cold War period, cable laying was "club" affair - only nationally-affiliated telecommunications companies could participate. AT&T facilitated all of the United States' transoceanic projects during this time, and built an number of cable stations on US shores.
Hawaiian Telecom, formerly the Hawaiian Telephone Company, has long been an investor and owner of US-Hawaiian systems, and has helped to bridge the United States to Asia.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: American Samoa Government,  Elandia

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Propelled by a strong wind, you land on a small, white sand beach dotted with coconut palms and volcanic rock formations in the southern part of Tutulia Island. This spot is now linked to Hawaii by underwater cable, but the same connection was once made by air. During World War II, the U.S. navy built an airfield here, which was later converted to receive passenger jets. By the 1960s, it had become a key stopping point for flights between Australia and Hawai‘i. As planes grew larger in the 1980s, however, they started to land at the expanded airport in nearby Samoa or bypass the islands entirely, no longer needing to refuel midway along their journeys. Today, the runways are mostly used by military and cargo transports with only the occasional passenger flight, making the U.S. territory feel remote. The cable didn’t do much to change this, since few locals can afford the steep Internet fees.

This two-part cable system links American Samoa and Samoa to Keawaula, Hawaii, where it joins networks reaching the U.S. mainland, Southeast Asia, and Australia. To lower costs, the system repurposed sections of the PacRim East cable between Hawaii and New Zealand, built in the 1990s as one of the first fiber-optic trans-Pacific links and retired in 2007. Despite being nearly 20 years old, the cable provides more than enough capacity for these small island groups.

The volcanic island of Jeju, meaning “province across the sea,” sits sixty miles off the coast of South Korea. Before the island became more closely linked to the mainland by tourism and underwater cables, it had a distinct language, culture, and ocean-based economy. Female free divers known as “haenyeo,” or “sea women,” have gathered shellfish and other marine life from the Korea Strait for generations, though their numbers are dwindling. In the 1990s, Jeju became a landing site for submarine electrical and communication lines. A branch of the Hong Kong-Japan-Korea (HJK) system surfaced in 1990, and in 1996, a high-voltage direct current cable joined the island’s power grid to the Korean Peninsula. With the decommissioning of HJK, Jeju fell out of the international cable circuit, redirecting all signal traffic through mainland hubs.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Along the shores of the Pearl River, across from Hong Kong, Macau was a fishing village until Portuguese traders, seeking a place to dry and store goods, established themselves there in the mid 16th century. Portuguese shacks gradually grew into a settlement, but much of the area remained governed by and inhabited by the Chinese. It was not until after the opium wars of the 19th century that China ceded the right of governance and occupation to Portugal in exchange for a promise that Portugal would help Hong Kong with trade and import taxes. Shortly thereafter, in 1884, a telegraph cable connected the two cities. The city remained a Portuguese colony until 1999, making it the last remaining European colony in Asia. That year, it was both transferred back to China, and linked via modern cable technology, SEA-WE-ME-3, which revived the earlier connection to Hong Kong.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The Pacific Cable Board cable was laid in 1902. It had been imagined for decades before it could actually be laid. It was only once the British came to value strategic communications that Sanford Fleming, a Canadian, was able to push the project through.
